skill.name: ena-database
skill.description: Access European Nucleotide Archive via API/FTP. Retrieve DNA/RNA sequences, raw reads (FASTQ), genome assemblies by accession, for genomics and bioinformatics pipelines. Supports multiple formats.
skill.summary: Access European Nucleotide Archive via API/FTP. Retrieve DNA/RNA sequences, raw reads (FASTQ), genom...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: The ena-database skill is a legitimate bioinformatics tool for accessing the European Nucleotide Archive. All static analysis findings are false positives - the 'external_commands' are markdown backticks in documentation, 'network' usage is legitimate API calls to ENA endpoints, 'hardcoded URLs' are official EBI service endpoints, 'weak cryptographic' findings are about MD5 checksums (standard for sequence data integrity), and 'Windows SAM' references are sample accession numbers (SAMN01, SAMN02) not Windows registry files.

content.user_title: Query European Nucleotide Archive for DNA/RNA sequences
content.value_statement: Bioinformatics researchers need efficient access to nucleotide sequence data from public repositories. This skill enables querying the European Nucleotide Archive to retrieve DNA/RNA sequences, raw reads, and genome assemblies via API calls.
actual_capabilities: Query ENA Portal API for samples, studies, assemblies by accession
Retrieve sequences in FASTA/FASTQ formats via Browser API
Search by taxonomy ID or scientific name
Download metadata in JSON, XML, or TSV formats
Access raw sequencing reads and genome assemblies
limitations: Requires internet connection to access ENA APIs
Rate limited to 50 requests per second
Large file downloads require FTP/Aspera clients
Some data may have embargo or access restrictions

use_cases.title: Download raw sequencing reads
use_cases.description: Retrieve FASTQ files for RNA-seq experiments from a specific study for differential expression analysis

use_cases.title: Find genome assemblies
use_cases.description: Search for complete genome assemblies of bacterial pathogens for comparative genomics studies

use_cases.title: Get taxonomic information
use_cases.description: Query taxonomic lineage and metadata for environmental samples in metagenomic studies

prompt_templates.title: Basic sequence retrieval
prompt_templates.prompt: Retrieve the nucleotide sequence for accession LN847353 in FASTA format from ENA

prompt_templates.title: Study data download
prompt_templates.scenario: Download all samples from a study
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all samples in study PRJEB12345 and list their accessions and metadata

prompt_templates.title: Taxonomic search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for all genome assemblies for Escherichia coli in ENA and return their accessions

prompt_templates.title: Complex query
prompt_templates.prompt: Find human RNA-seq experiments from 2023 with at least 10 million reads using ENA Portal API

best_practices: Use specific accession numbers when possible for faster queries
Implement rate limiting to stay within 50 requests/second limit
Cache taxonomy lookups when processing multiple records
anti_patterns: Iterating API calls for bulk downloads - use FTP instead
Hardcoding URLs - use the skill's built-in endpoints
Parsing XML with regex - use proper XML libraries

faq.question: What is ENA?
faq.answer: The European Nucleotide Archive is a comprehensive public repository for nucleotide sequence data maintained by EMBL-EBI

faq.question: How do I find data by organism?
faq.answer: Use tax_tree(taxon_id) or scientific name queries in the Portal API to find all data for a species

faq.question: What formats are available?
faq.answer: Sequences: FASTA/FASTQ/EMBL. Metadata: JSON/XML/TSV. Raw reads: SRA/FASTQ/BAM/CRAM

faq.question: How do I download large datasets?
faq.answer: Use FTP links from filereport endpoint or enaBrowserTools for bulk downloads instead of API

faq.question: Are there usage limits?
faq.answer: Yes, 50 requests per second. Use bulk operations and implement exponential backoff for 429 errors

faq.question: How do I cite ENA data?
faq.answer: Cite using the study/project accession (PRJEB/PRJNA) and include specific accessions used in your analysis
